author: Ewin Hannan
title: Allegedly corrupt CFMEU organiser was ALP branch president
text:
Former CFMEU organiser Halafihi "Fihi" Kivalu outside the hearing on Tuesday. Jamila Toderas Share on twitter by Ewin Hannan A former construction union organiser accused of extorting more than $150,000 from employers was president of an ALP branch in the ACT.
The Australian Financial Review has confirmed that Halafihi Kivalu, now subject to damaging evidence before the trade union royal commission, was president of the ALP's Dickson-Morning sub-branch until May this year.
Zach Smith, the sub-branch's current president, said on Thursday that Mr Kivalu had been president for 12 months. Mr Smith is an organiser with the Construction, Forestry, Mining and Energy Union
Mr Kivalu admitted to the commission on Thursday that he took $60,000 from the contractor, Elias Taleb. But he claimed the payments were done voluntarily by Mr Taleb.
But the commission was played a recording of a telephone conversation between Mr Kivalu and Mr Taleb on April 10 this year in which Mr Kivalu demanded payment of $85,000.
"Remember we agreed on fu--king 50 grand for the Morris job," Mr Kivalu is recorded as saying during an expletive-laden conversation with Mr Taleb.
He told Mr Taleb that there was a $35,000 payment or a separate job at Yarralumla "that you still haven't paid for".
Mr Kivalu was expelled this week by the CFMEU after Mr Taleb told the commission he paid more than $135,000 to Mr Kivalu to work in Canberra.
 Three other employers gave evidence that they made payments to Mr Kivalu.
Giving evidence to the commission on Thursday, Mr Kivalu admitted that Mr Taleb had paid him about $60,000 but claimed he had done it voluntarily and they were friends.
"This was the amount of money that he offered me with as view to me assisting his business to get work," he said in his witness statement.
He insisted the CFMEU had no knowledge of his actions.
